message.content:
We have to “build” the value of our fixed (non‐current) assets from the transactions that affect that account. In our case the only transactions that affect non-current assets are the “initial” fixed asset balance (provided on 2023‑12‑31) plus any subsequent fixed asset purchases (which are “Fixed Assets Purchase” transactions) minus the “depreciation” charged afterward.

Step 1. The “Initial” entry on 2023‑12‑31 shows:
  Fixed Assets = 5,000,000.00

Step 2. Identify the additional fixed asset purchase transactions (their “type” is “Fixed Assets Purchase”):
• A. A row with amount 256859.19 (e.g. “Processing Equipment4”)
• B. A row with amount 171985.91 (e.g. “Storage Facilities5”)
• C. A row with amount 55577.41 (e.g. “Production Line6”)
• D. A row with amount 73932.79 (e.g. “Production Line8”)
• E. A row with amount 117840.57 (e.g. “Production Line7”)

We sum these:
  256859.19 + 171985.91 = 428845.10  
  428845.10 + 55577.41 = 484422.51  
  484422.51 + 73932.79 = 558355.30  
  558355.30 + 117840.57 = 676195.87

Step 3. Check the depreciation charge. There is one “Depreciation” transaction:
  Depreciation amount = 45748.43

Step 4. Compute net additions to the fixed assets = (additional fixed asset purchases) – depreciation  
  Net addition = 676195.87 – 45748.43 = 630447.44

Step 5. Finally, compute the ending (final) fixed assets value = initial fixed assets + net additions  
  Ending Value = 5000000.00 + 630447.44 = 5630447.44

Thus, our answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Total Non-current Assets Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Total Non-current Assets End Value": "5630447.44"
  }
}
